title: 2 states launch an investigation of the NFL over gender discrimination and harassment
description: The California and New York attorneys general say they are seeking information from the NFL on allegations of gender pay disparities, harassment and gender and race discrimination.

title: Shares of smaller lenders sink once again, reviving fears about the banking sector
description: PacWest and Western Alliance were among the smaller lenders that saw shares tumble even as the banks sought to reassure their customers and investors..

title: He's trying to fix the IRS and has $80 billion to play with. This is his plan
description: There are two competing trends: The population of the U.S. has grown at the same time as the workforce of the IRS has shrunk. A 10-year, $80 billion plan aims to tackle the agency's troubles.

title: The best picket signs of the Hollywood writers' strike
description: As the Writers Guild of America began its first strike in 15 years, union members let loose with quips to studio executives, as they picketed outside companies like Netflix, Sony and NBCUniversal.

title: Jury finds that Ed Sheeran didn't copy Marvin Gaye classic 'Let's Get It On'
description: A federal jury in New York concluded Thursday that the British singer didn't steal key components of Marvin Gaye's 1970s classic "Let's Get It On" when he created his hit song "Thinking Out Loud."

title: 'Fresh Air' welcomes new co-host Tonya Mosley
description: Based in Los Angeles, Mosley previously served as a correspondent and host of Here & Now, and as a host and Silicon Valley bureau chief at KQED in San Francisco. She hosts the podcast Truth Be Told.

title: Financier buys Jeffrey Epstein's private islands, with plans to create a resort
description: Financier Stephen Deckoff paid $60 million for Great St. James and Little St. James. He hopes to open a resort on the islands by sometime in 2025.

title: Amid a child labor crisis, U.S. state governments are loosening regulations
description: New York Times journalist Hannah Dreier says hundreds of thousands of immigrant kids are working illegally. Washington Post reporter Jacob Bogage explains how states are loosening child labor laws.

title: 'Gone to the Wolves' masterfully portrays the heavy metal scene of the '80s and '90s
description: John Wray's latest novel is a powerful and juicy story about a particular time, subculture, and the ways people can find themselves in — or can deliberately disappear into — fandom.

title: For May the 4th, Carrie Fisher of 'Star Wars' is getting a Hollywood Walk of Fame star
description: The honor for the late actress, who played Princess Leia and many other roles in a lengthy career, will be accepted by her daughter and fellow Star Wars actress Billie Lourd.

title: Jury convicts Enrique Tarrio of the Proud Boys on seditious conspiracy charge
description: After four months of trial, a jury has convicted Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio and other members of the far-right club of seditious conspiracy for their roles on Jan. 6, 2021.

title: Why the Koh-i-noor diamond won't make an appearance at King Charles III's coronation
description: The royal family has decided to leave the 105-carat gem out of this weekend's coronation ceremony. The Koh-i-noor has become a focus of anti-colonial anger. India wants it back.

title: A Michigan school district has banned students from carrying backpacks
description: Flint Community Schools said it has concerns about the national landscape of gun violence across the nation. The ban went into effect Monday.

title: Germany and Italy clamp down on Italian mob with raids and arrests
description: The police operation, coordinated by European Union judicial cooperation agency Eurojust, aimed to dismantle a network that includes the 'ndrangheta, Colombian drug producers and paramilitary groups.

title: New York state is set to ban fossil fuels in new construction starting in 2026
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said the move would help the state lower carbon emissions and transition to clean energy sources.

title: Library funding becomes the 'nuclear option' as the battle over books escalates
description: Some libraries are now facing an existential threat: They could lose their public funding over books deemed inappropriate for young readers.

title: Biden administration warns consumers to avoid medical credit cards
description: Americans paid an estimated $1 billion in interest on medical debt in just three years, a federal agency finds. This includes use of credit cards often pitched in doctors' and dentists' offices.

title: Advocates in Florida clamor for a fix for the formerly incarcerated who want to vote
description: There's no easy way for Floridians returning from prison to figure out what's needed to regain their voting rights. And advocates are critical of language set to be added to voter registration cards.

title: As the pandemic winds down, anti-vaccine activists are building a legal network
description: They're aiming to bring together lawyers who have brought COVID-19 and vaccine-related cases to court with experts and build a body of law to combat future public health orders.

title: John Legend knows the obstacles of life after prison. He wants you to know them too
description: When incarcerated people leave prison, are they actually free? NPR's Michel Martin talks to singer/songwriter John Legend about a new documentary he narrates.

title: Unlikely connection: college students in Ukraine and the U.S. form a bond
description: Learning American pop culture while attending college during a war: Students in Dnipro, Ukraine, and Golden, Colo., form an unlikely connection.

title: An unpublished novel by Gabriel García Márquez is set for release next year
description: Arriving 10 years after the author's death, the roughly 150-page novel will contain five sections centered around a character named Ana Magdalena Bach.

title: Think you're a Taurus? Earth's wobble sees things differently
description: Our view of the constellations has changed since they were first mapped thousands of years ago. That new perspective could also mess with your horoscope.

title: Dealers still sell Hyundais and Kias vulnerable to theft, but insurance is hard to get
description: Some insurance companies have stopped issuing new policies for models that are subject to a high rate of thefts, but consumers are still able to buy the cars.

title: The U.S. has more banks than anywhere on Earth. That shapes the economy in many ways
description: The U.S. has more than 4,500 banks – more banks than any other country. That huge number of lenders has shaped the economy in countless ways, but it also can pose risks.

title: The latest to be evacuated from California's floods? Bunnies
description: Rising rivers are stranding endangered riparian brush rabbits in California. Wildlife officials are searching out and relocating hundreds of them to help protect the species.

title: As fentanyl deaths surge, some state lawmakers push back against 'harm reduction'
description: The Biden administration is embracing health care efforts designed to reduce the deadly impact of fentanyl addiction, but many state legislatures are resisting the "harm reduction" approach.

title: Eli Lilly says an experimental drug slows Alzheimer's worsening
description: In the 18-month trial, people in the early stages of Alzheimer's who received infusions of donanemab showed 35% less decline in thinking skills compared to those given a dummy drug, Lilly announced.

title: McDonald's franchises face more than $200,000 in fines for child-labor law violations
description: Three franchisees operating McDonald's locations in Maryland, Kentucky, Ohio and Indiana collectively had 305 minors working illegally. They are ordered to pay more than $200,000 in civil penalties.

title: Tyre Nichols' autopsy reveals brain injuries from blunt force trauma, attorneys say
description: The family of Tyre Nichols and their attorneys were briefed on his official autopsy results Wednesday, nearly four months after his death.
